title: 110_hr2466
content: The Act titled "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" increases penalties for violent crimes in aid of racketeering activity. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" amends Section 1959(a) of title 18, United States Code, to impose harsh penalties for committing violent crimes in furtherance of racketeering activities. Penalties include death or life imprisonment for crimes resulting in death, and imprisonment for kidnapping, sexual abuse, maiming, or assault causing serious bodily injury. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" amends Section 1959(a) of title 18, United States Code, imposing harsh penalties for violent crimes in connection with racketeering. Penalties include life imprisonment for assault causing serious bodily injury, with venue options for prosecution. SEC. 102 of the Controlled Substances Act amends Part D to address murder and violent crimes related to drug trafficking. Sec. 424 of the Controlled Substances Act outlines the sentencing for committing a crime of violence during a drug trafficking crime, including death penalty or life imprisonment for certain offenses. Sec. 424 of the Controlled Substances Act allows for prosecution in the district where the crime occurred or where the drug trafficking crime can be prosecuted. Definitions for "crime of violence" and "drug trafficking crime" are provided in the section. SEC. 103 amends penalties for using a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. SEC. 104 provides an exemption for off-duty law enforcement officers under the Gun-Free School Zones Act. Section 922(q)(2)(B)(vi) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "or while off-duty" before the semicolon. The Attorney General, in consultation with State and local officials, shall establish anti-gang task forces consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal gangs. Funding and personnel reassignment will be provided for the task forces' operation and meetings to ensure effective team operation. The anti-gang task forces will consist of agents and officers from various law enforcement agencies, including the FBI, DEA, ATF, US Marshals, DHS, HUD, state and local law enforcement, and prosecutors. $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2011 for this purpose.
